#Text=Learning Objectives
#Text=By the end of this section , you will be able to :
#Text=Describe cognition
#Text=Distinguish concepts and prototypes
#Text=Explain the difference between natural and artificial concepts
#Text=Imagine all of your thoughts as if they were physical entities , swirling rapidly inside your mind .
#Text=How is it possible that the brain is able to move from one thought to the next in an organized , orderly fashion ?
#Text=The brain is endlessly perceiving , processing , planning , organizing , and remembering — it is always active .
#Text=Yet , you do n’t notice most of your brain ’s activity as you move throughout your daily routine .
#Text=This is only one facet of the complex processes involved in cognition .
#Text=Simply put , cognition is thinking , and it encompasses the processes associated with perception , knowledge , problem solving , judgment , language , and memory .

#Text=Scientists who study cognition are searching for ways to understand how we integrate , organize , and utilize our conscious cognitive experiences without being aware of all of the unconscious work that our brains are doing ( for example , Kahneman , 2011 ) .
#Text=Cognition
#Text=Upon waking each morning , you begin thinking — contemplating the tasks that you must complete that day .
#Text=In what order should you run your errands ?
#Text=Should you go to the bank , the cleaners , or the grocery store first ?
#Text=Can you get these things done before you head to class or will they need to wait until school is done ?
#Text=These thoughts are one example of cognition at work .
#Text=Exceptionally complex , cognition is an essential feature of human consciousness , yet not all aspects of cognition are consciously experienced .
#Text=Cognitive psychology is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think .

#Text=It attempts to explain how and why we think the way we do by studying the interactions among human thinking , emotion , creativity , language , and problem solving , in addition to other cognitive processes .

#Text=Cognitive psychologists strive to determine and measure different types of intelligence , why some people are better at problem solving than others , and how emotional intelligence affects success in the workplace , among countless other topics .
#Text=They also sometimes focus on how we organize thoughts and information gathered from our environments into meaningful categories of thought , which will be discussed later .
#Text=Concepts and Prototypes
#Text=The human nervous system is capable of handling endless streams of information .
#Text=The senses serve as the interface between the mind and the external environment , receiving stimuli and translating it into nervous impulses that are transmitted to the brain .
#Text=The brain then processes this information and uses the relevant pieces to create thoughts , which can then be expressed through language or stored in memory for future use .
#Text=To make this process more complex , the brain does not gather information from external environments only .
#Text=When thoughts are formed , the brain also pulls information from emotions and memories ( Figure 7.2 ) .
#Text=Emotion and memory are powerful influences on both our thoughts and behaviors .
#Text=Figure 7.2
#Text=Sensations and information are received by our brains , filtered through emotions and memories , and processed to become thoughts .
#Text=In order to organize this staggering amount of information , the brain has developed a file cabinet of sorts in the mind .
#Text=The different files stored in the file cabinet are called concepts .
#Text=Concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information , images , ideas , or memories , such as life experiences .
#Text=Concepts are , in many ways , big ideas that are generated by observing details , and categorizing and combining these details into cognitive structures .
#Text=You use concepts to see the relationships among the different elements of your experiences and to keep the information in your mind organized and accessible .

#Text=Concepts are informed by our semantic memory ( you will learn more about semantic memory in a later chapter ) and are present in every aspect of our lives ; however , one of the easiest places to notice concepts is inside a classroom , where they are discussed explicitly .
#Text=When you study United States history , for example , you learn about more than just individual events that have happened in America ’s past .
#Text=You absorb a large quantity of information by listening to and participating in discussions , examining maps , and reading first-hand accounts of people ’s lives .
#Text=Your brain analyzes these details and develops an overall understanding of American history .
#Text=In the process , your brain gathers details that inform and refine your understanding of related concepts like democracy , power , and freedom .
#Text=Concepts can be complex and abstract , like justice , or more concrete , like types of birds .
#Text=In psychology , for example , Piaget ’s stages of development are abstract concepts .
#Text=Some concepts , like tolerance , are agreed upon by many people , because they have been used in various ways over many years .
#Text=Other concepts , like the characteristics of your ideal friend or your family ’s birthday traditions , are personal and individualized .
#Text=In this way , concepts touch every aspect of our lives , from our many daily routines to the guiding principles behind the way governments function .
#Text=Another technique used by your brain to organize information is the identification of prototypes for the concepts you have developed .
#Text=A prototype is the best example or representation of a concept .
#Text=For example , for the category of civil disobedience , your prototype could be Rosa Parks .
#Text=Her peaceful resistance to segregation on a city bus in Montgomery , Alabama , is a recognizable example of civil disobedience .
#Text=Or your prototype could be Mohandas Gandhi , sometimes called Mahatma Gandhi ( “ Mahatma ” is an honorific title ) ( Figure 7.3 ) .
#Text=Figure 7.3
#Text=In 1930 , Mohandas Gandhi led a group in peaceful protest against a British tax on salt in India .

#Text=Mohandas Gandhi served as a nonviolent force for independence for India while simultaneously demanding that Buddhist , Hindu , Muslim , and Christian leaders — both Indian and British — collaborate peacefully .
#Text=Although he was not always successful in preventing violence around him , his life provides a steadfast example of the civil disobedience prototype ( Constitutional Rights Foundation , 2013 ) .

#Text=Just as concepts can be abstract or concrete , we can make a distinction between concepts that are functions of our direct experience with the world and those that are more artificial in nature .
